title: Erdős Problem #310: Unit Fractions with Bounded Denominator
description: For any α-dense subset A of {1,...,N}, there exists a subset S whose unit fraction sum equals a/b with a ≤ b = O_α(1). Solved by Liu-Sawhney (2024) building on Bloom (2021).

overview.historicalContext: Unit fractions (Egyptian fractions) have been studied since antiquity. The ancient Egyptians represented all fractions as sums of distinct unit fractions. Erdős asked a natural question about how 'simple' a rational can be represented using unit fractions from a dense subset of {1,...,N}. Here 'simple' means small denominator, bounded by a function of the density parameter α. This connects classical number theory to modern density combinatorics.
overview.problemStatement: Let α > 0 and N ≥ 1. Is it true that for any A ⊆ {1,...,N} with |A| ≥ αN, there exists some S ⊆ A such that a/b = Σ_{n∈S} 1/n with a ≤ b = O_α(1)?
overview.proofStrategy: Liu and Sawhney (2024) observed that Bloom's density conjecture result (2021) implies a positive answer. They proved a more precise version: if (log N)^{-1/7+o(1)} ≤ α ≤ 1/2, then there exists S ⊆ A with a/b = Σ_{n∈S} 1/n where a ≤ b ≤ exp(O(1/α)). The bound exp(O(1/α)) is sharp.
keyInsights: Bloom's theorem guarantees subsets with unit fraction sums close to 1
The bound b ≤ exp(O(1/α)) is exponential in 1/α and cannot be improved
The result requires a minimum density threshold depending on log N
Classical Egyptian fraction theory provides existence but not the bounded denominator property
The problem connects density combinatorics to Diophantine approximation

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #310 is solved: YES, every α-dense subset of {1,...,N} contains a subset whose unit fraction sum is a simple rational with bounded denominator. Liu-Sawhney (2024) proved the precise bound b ≤ exp(O(1/α)), which is optimal.
conclusion.implications: This result bridges classical Egyptian fraction theory with modern density combinatorics. It shows that dense sets are 'rich enough' to construct simple rationals from unit fractions, with quantitative control over the complexity.
openQuestions: Can the density threshold (log N)^{-1/7} be improved?
Are there algorithmic methods to find the optimal subset S efficiently?
What happens for structured sets A beyond density conditions?
